subject: Gardening
title: Aboriginal Fire-Stick Farming
description: A short lesson to help you apply Aboriginal Fire-Stick Farming.

hook.text: Aboriginal Australians burned the landscape on purpose for 65,000 years. It wasn't destructionâ€”it was farming.

buildup.text: Burns cleared undergrowth, recycled nutrients, and triggered seed germination of food plants like yam daisies.

discovery.text: Fire-stick farming created the open eucalyptus woodlands Europeans mistook for 'wilderness.

twist.text: When colonists stopped Aboriginal burning, fuel loads built up. The result: catastrophic megafires like in 2020.

climax.text: Land managers are returning to Aboriginal fire knowledge. 65,000 years of practice outperforms decades of suppression.

punchline.text: The oldest farming in history uses fire, not plows.

quiz.question: What happened when colonial governments stopped Aboriginal controlled burning?
options: Forests grew thicker and healthier than ever before
Fuel loads built up, leading to catastrophic megafires
New plant species colonized the previously burned areas
